{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Speciesbox | name = Iberian lynx | taxon = Lynx pardinus | authority = ([[Coenraad Jacob Temminck|Temminck]], 1827) | status = EN | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=iucn>{{Cite iucn |journal=[[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] |publisher=[[IUCN]] |title=''Lynx pardinus'' | author = Rodr√≠guez, A. | author2 = Calzada, J. | last-author-amp = yes | volume = 2015 | page = e.T12520A50655794 | date = 2015 |url=https://www.iucnredlist.org/species/12520/50655794 |doi=10.2305/IUCN.UK.2015-2.RLTS.T12520A50655794.en |access-date=29 October 2018}}</ref> | image = Linces19.jpg | range_map = Mapa distribuicao lynx pardinus defasado.png | range_map_caption = 1980 range map}}
The '''Iberian lynx''' (''Lynx pardinus'') is a wild [[felidae|cat]] species native to the [[Iberian Peninsula]] in southwestern Europe that is listed as [[endangered species|Endangered]] on the [[IUCN Red List]].<ref name=iucn /> It preys almost exclusively on the [[European rabbit]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rodr√≠guez-Hidalgo |first1=A. |last2=Lloveras |first2=L.|last3=Moreno-Garc√≠a |first3=M. |last4=Saladi√© |first4=P. |last5=Canals |first5=A. |last6=Nadal |first6=J. |year=2013 |title=Feeding behaviour and taphonomic characterization of non-ingested rabbit remains produced by the Iberian lynx (''Lynx pardinus'') |journal=Journal of Archaeological Science|volume=40 |issue=7 |pages=3031‚Äì3045 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Lluis_Lloveras/publication/236208653_Feeding_behavior_and_taphonomic_characterization_of_non-ingested_rabbit_remains_produced_by_the_Iberian_lynx_(Lynx_pardinus)/links/00b4952558742146b9000000.pdf |doi=10.1016/j.jas.2013.03.006}}</ref> In the 20th century, the Iberian lynx population declined because of sharp declines in rabbit populations, caused by [[myxomatosis]], [[rabbit haemorrhagic disease]] and overhunting, fragmentation of grassland and forest habitats and [[poaching]].<ref name=Fordham2013>{{cite journal |last1=Fordham |first1=D.A. |last2=Ak√ßakaya |first2=H.R. |last3=Brook |first3=B.W. |last4=Rodr√≠guez |first4=A. |last5=Alves |first5=P.C.|last6=Civantos|first6=E.|last7=Trivino|first7=M.|last8=Watts|first8=M.J.|last9=Araujo |first9=M.B. |year=2013 |title=Adapted conservation measures are required to save the Iberian lynx in a changing climate |journal=Nature Climate Change |volume=3 | issue = 10 |pages=899‚Äì903 |url=http://digital.csic.es/bitstream/10261/84387/1/Fordham_Nat%20Clim%20Change_13.pdf |doi=10.1038/nclimate1954 |bibcode=2013NatCC...3..899F}}</ref>
By the turn of the 21st century, the Iberian lynx was on the verge of extinction, as only about 100 individuals survived in two isolated subpopulations in [[Andalusia]]. Conservation measures implemented since 2002 included improving habitat, restocking of rabbits, [[Translocation (wildlife conservation)|translocating]] and [[Species reintroduction|re-introducing]] Iberian lynxes, so that by 2012 the population had increased to 326 individuals.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lopez|first1=G.|last2=Lopez|first2=M.|last3=Fernandez|first3=L.|last4=Ruiz|first4=G.|last5=Arenas|first5=R.|last6=Del Rey|first6=T.|last7=Gil|first7=J.M.|last8=Garrote|first8=G.|last9=Garcia|first9=M.|last10=Simon|first10=M.|year=2012 |title=Population development of the Iberian lynx since 2002 |journal=Cat News |volume=57 |pages=34}}</ref> As an attempt to save this species from extinction, projects under the EU [[The LIFE Programme|LIFE Programme]] have undertaken habitat preservation, lynx population monitoring, and rabbit population management.<ref name=pone2012>{{cite journal |journal= PLoS ONE |title= Gene sets for utilization of Primary and Secondary Nutrition supplies in the Distal gut of Endangered Iberian Lynx |last1= Alcaide |first1=M. |last2=Messina |first2=E. |last3=Richter |first3=M. |last4=Bargiela |first4=R. |last5=Peplies|first5=J.|last6=Huws|first6=S.A.|last7=Newbold|first7= C.J. |last8=Golyshin|first8=P.N. |last9=Sim√≥n|first9=M.A. |last10=L√≥pez|first10=G.|last11=Yakimov|first11=M.M. |year= 2012 |volume= 7 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0051521 |pmid= 23251564 |pmc= 3520844 |issue= 12 |pages=e51521|bibcode=2012PLoSO...751521A}}</ref>
Formerly considered a subspecies of the [[Eurasian lynx]] (''Lynx lynx''), the Iberian lynx is now classified as a separate species. Both species occurred together in [[Central Europe]] in the [[Pleistocene]] and evolved as distinct species in the [[Late Pleistocene]].<ref name=Sim√≥n2012>{{cite book |author=Sim√≥n, M.A. |year=2012 |title=Ten years conserving the Iberian lynx |publisher=Consejer√≠a de Agricultura, Pesca y Medio Ambiente. Junta de Andalus√≠a |location=Seville |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VhFEETrncwEC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn=9788492807802 }}</ref> The Iberian lynx is thought to have evolved from ''[[Lynx issiodorensis]]''.<ref name=pmoe68>{{cite book |first= B. |last= Kurt√©n |title= Pleistocene Mammals of Europe |year= 1968 |publisher=Aldine Transaction |location=London, New Brunswick}}</ref>
== Characteristics == [[File:Linces1.jpg|left|thumb|Closeup of the Iberian lynx]]
The Iberian lynx has a bright yellowish to tawny colored spotted and short fur, a short body, long legs, a short tail, a small head with tufted ears and facial whiskers, called a ruff. Head and body length of males is {{convert|74.7|to|82|cm|in|abbr=on}} with a {{convert|12.5|to|16|cm|in|abbr=on}} long tail and a weight of {{convert|7|to|15.9|kg|lb|abbr=on}}. Males are larger than females who have a head-to-body-length of approximately {{convert|68.2|to|77.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} and can weigh {{convert|9.2|to|10|kg|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref name=WCoW>{{cite book |first= M. |last= Sunquist |first2= F. |last2= Sunquist |year=2002 |title= Wild cats of the World |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location= Chicago |pages= 177‚Äì184 |isbn= 0-226-77999-8}}</ref>
The spot pattern of the fur varies from uniformly and densely distributed small spots to more elongate spots arranged in lines that decrease in size from the back towards the sides.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Beltr√°n|first1=J.F.|last2=Delibes|first2=M. |year=1993 |title=Physical characteristics of Iberian lynxes (''Lynx pardinus'') from Do√±ana, southwestern Spain |journal=Journal of Mammalogy |volume=74 | issue = 4 |pages=852‚Äì862 |doi=10.2307/1382423}}</ref>
== Distribution and habitat == The Iberian lynx was once present throughout the Iberian Peninsula and southern France. In the 1950s, the northern population extended from the [[Mediterranean]] to [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] and parts of northern Portugal, and the southern population from central to southern Spain.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Clavero|first1=M.|last2=Delibes|first2=M. |year=2013 |title=Using historical accounts to set conservation baselines: the case of Lynx species in Spain |journal=Biodiversity and Conservation |volume=22 | issue = 8 |pages=1691‚Äì1702 |doi=10.1007/s10531-013-0506-4}}</ref> Populations declined from 15 subpopulations in the 1940s to only two subpopulations in the early 1990s, most noticeably in [[Montes de Toledo]] and [[Sierra Morena]]. Before 1973, it was present in [[Sierra de Gata]], Montes de Toledo, eastern Sierra Morena, Sierra de Relumbrar and [[Do√±ana National Park|Do√±ana coastal plains]]. Between the early 1960s and 2000, it has lost about 80% of its former range.<ref name=AC2008>{{cite journal |last1=Alda |first1=F. |last2=Inog√©s |first2=J. |last3=Alcaraz |first3=L. |last4=Oria |first4=J. |last5=Aranda |first5=A. |last6=Doadrio |first6=I. |year=2008 |title=Looking for the Iberian lynx in central Spain: a needle in a hay stack? |journal=Animal Conservation |issn=1367-9430 |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=297‚Äì305 |doi=10.1111/j.1469-1795.2008.00185.x}}</ref><ref name=JM2011>{{cite journal |last1=Gil-Sanchez |first1=J.M. |last2=McCain |first2=E.B. |year=2011 |title=Former range and decline of the Iberian lynx (''Lynx pardinus'') reconstructed using verified records |journal=Journal of Mammalogy |volume=92 |issue=5 |pages=1081‚Äì1090 |doi=10.1644/10-MAMM-A-381.1}}</ref> It is now restricted to very limited areas in southern Spain, with breeding only confirmed in Sierra Morena and Do√±ana coastal plains.<ref name=Sim√≥n2012/>
A study of [[mitochondrial DNA]] from fossil remains, published in March 2015, suggests the Iberian lynx had a wider range during the [[Late Pleistocene]] and [[Holocene]], including northern Italy and southern France.{{r|QSR150315}}
The Iberian lynx prefers [[heterogeneous]] environments of open grassland mixed with dense shrubs such as [[Arbutus unedo|strawberry tree]], [[Pistacia lentiscus|mastic]], and [[juniper]], and trees such as [[holm oak]] and [[cork oak]]. It is now largely restricted to mountainous areas.
== Ecology and behaviour== {{Multiple image | direction = vertical | align = top | header = Iberian lynx hunting [[common quail]] ''Coturnix coturnix'' | width1 = 240 | image1 = Iberian Lynx catching his prey.jpg | caption1 = Swiping with right paw with claws extended | width2 = 240 | image2 = Iberian Lynx eating bird.jpg | caption2 = Caught prey in mouth }} The Iberian lynx preys foremost on the [[European rabbit]] (''Oryctolagus cuniculus'') for the bulk of its diet, supplemented by [[red-legged partridge]], [[rodent]]s and to a smaller degree also on wild [[ungulate]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Palomares|first1=F.|last2=Delibes|first2=M.|last3=Revilla|first3=E.|last4=Calzada|first4=J.|last5=Frediani|first5=J.M. |year=2001 |title=Spatial ecology of Iberian lynx and abundance of European rabbits in south-western Spain |journal=Wildlife Monographs |volume=148 |pages=1‚Äì36}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gil-S√°nchez|first1=J.M.|last2=Ballesteros-Duper√≥n|first2=E.|last3=Bueno-Segura|first3=J.F.|year=2006 |title=Feeding ecology of the Iberian lynx ''Lynx pardinus'' in eastern Sierra Morena (Southern Spain) |journal=Acta Theriologica |volume= 51 |pages= 85‚Äì90 |doi=10.1007/bf03192659}}</ref><ref name=LopezBao2011>{{cite journal|last1= L√≥pez‚ÄêBao|first1=J.V.|last2=Palomares|first2=F.|last3=Rodr√≠guez|first3=A.|last4=Ferreras|first4=P.|title= Intraspecific interference influences the use of prey hotspots |journal= OIKOS |volume= 120 |issue= 10 |year= 2011 |pages= 1489‚Äì1496 |doi= 10.1111/j.1600-0706.2011.19194.x}}</ref> It sometimes preys on young [[fallow deer]], [[roe deer]], [[mouflon]], and ducks.{{r|DelibesRod2000}} A male requires one rabbit per day while a female raising kittens will eat three per day.<ref name=ward>{{cite book |url=http://wardenvironment.ch/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Ward_REP_The_Iberian_lynx_emergency.pdf |first=D. |last=Ward |title=The Iberian Lynx Emergency |year=2004 |publisher=EU commissioned report}}</ref> The Iberian species has low adaptability‚Äîit continued to rely heavily on rabbits (75% of its food intake) despite the latter's repeated population crashes due to two diseases: [[myxomatosis]], which spread to Iberia after a physician intentionally introduced it in France in 1952, and [[rabbit haemorrhagic disease]] beginning in 1988.<ref name=Fordham2013/> There were two major outbreaks of the latter in 2011 and 2012.<ref name=efe130917 /> Recovery has occurred in some areas‚Äîin 2013, rabbit overpopulation was reported south of [[C√≥rdoba, Andalusia|C√≥rdoba]], causing damage to transport infrastructure and farms.<ref name=abc130805 /> In December 2013, however, it was reported that wildlife officials were concerned about the spread of a new strain of the hemorraghic disease, affecting mainly young rabbits.<ref name=elpais131215 />{{r|Phys150211}} Sierra Morena's rabbit population was worst affected, falling from an average of three per hectare to less than one‚Äîbelow the minimum required level of 1.5 to two per hectare.<ref name=ideal140514 /> Forced to travel greater distances for food, the lynx became more susceptible to death in road accidents, particularly on [[Autov√≠a A-4]].<ref name=ideal140514 />
It competes for prey with the [[red fox]], the [[Egyptian mongoose]] (''Herpestes ichneumon'') and the [[wildcat]]. Also, it often kills other smaller carnivores such as the [[red fox]], the [[Egyptian mongoose]], and the [[Common genet]] (''Genetta genetta'').<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Fedriani | first1 = J.M. | last2 = Palomares | first2 = F. | last3 = Delibes | first3 = M. | year = 1999 | title = Niche relations among three sympatric Mediterranean carnivores | url = | journal = Oecologia | volume = 121 | issue = | pages = 138‚Äì148 | doi=10.1007/s004420050915| bibcode = 1999Oecol.121..138F }}</ref> The species is solitary and hunts alone; it will stalk its prey or lie in wait for hours behind a bush or rock until the prey is sufficiently close to pounce in a few strides.
The Iberian lynx is smaller than its northern relatives, and typically hunts smaller animals, usually no larger than [[hare]]s. It also differs in habitat choice, with Iberian lynx inhabiting open [[scrubland]] and Eurasian lynx inhabiting forests.<ref name=iucncsg />
A lynx, especially with younger animals, will roam widely, with ranges reaching more than {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Its territory (‚âà{{convert|10|to|20|km2|mi2|abbr=on}}) is also dependent on how much food is available.<ref name=ward /> Adult Iberian lynx tend to require a minimum amount of space of {{convert|5| to |20|km2|mi2|abbr=on}}, and a population of 50 breeding females requires about {{convert|500|km2|mi2|abbr=on}} of habitat area.<ref name=LopezBao2011 /> Nonetheless, once established, ranges tend to be stable in size over many years, the boundaries often being along man-made roads and trails. The Iberian lynx [[Spraying (animal behavior)|marks its territory with its urine]], droppings left in existing tracks through the vegetation, and scratch marks on the barks of trees.<ref name=WCoW />
== Reproduction == [[File:Lince Ib√©rico Do√±ana.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Specimen in the [[Do√±ana National Park]]]] During the mating season the female leaves her territory in search of a male. The typical [[gestation]] period is about two months; the kittens are born between March and September, with a peak of births in March and April. A litter consists of two or three (rarely one, four or five) kittens weighing between {{convert|200|and|250|g|oz}}.
The kittens become independent at 7 to 10 months old, but remain with the mother until around 20 months old. Survival of the young depends heavily on the availability of prey species. In the wild, both males and females reach sexual maturity at the age of one year, though in practice they rarely breed until a territory becomes vacant; one female was known not to breed until five years old when its mother died. The maximum longevity in the wild is 13 years.<ref name=iucncsg /><ref name=adw />
Siblings become violent towards one another between 30 and 60 days, peaking at 45 days. A kitten will frequently kill its littermate in a brutal fight. It is unknown why these episodes of aggression occur, though many scientists believe it is related to a change in hormones when a kitten switches from its mother's milk to meat. Others believe it is related to hierarchy, and "[[survival of the fittest]]".
Difficulty in finding mates has led to more inbreeding, which results in fewer kittens and a greater rate of non-traumatic death.{{r|EJWR2012}} Inbreeding leads to lower semen quality and greater rates of infertility in males, hindering efforts to increase the species' fitness.{{r|CB2013}}
== Conservation == The Iberian lynx has been downlisted from [[critically endangered species]] to [[endangered species]] thanks to reintroduction and other conservation actions. Its small population makes the cat especially vulnerable to extinction from sudden random events such as a natural disaster or disease.{{r|Vargas2008}} Conservation measures include restoring its native habitat, maintaining the wild rabbit population, reducing unnatural causes of death, and captive breeding for release.<ref name=Vargas2008 /> The Spanish National Commission for the Protection of Nature endorsed the Iberian Lynx Ex Situ Conservation Breeding Program to serve as a "safety net" by managing the captive population and also to "help establish new Iberian lynx free-ranging populations through reintroduction programmes."<ref name=Vargas2008 /> Before release of captive-bred cats, their natural habit may be simulated to prepare them for life in the wild.<ref name=Vargas2008 /> A 2006 study used a non-intrusive monitoring system involving cameras to monitor the demographics of both lynxes and rabbits residing in Sierra Morena.{{r|GilSanchez2010}} Supplemental food sources could be provided if wild rabbits suffered a decline.<ref name=GilSanchez2010 />
The Iberian lynx and its habitat are fully protected, and they are no longer legally hunted. Threats include habitat loss, vehicle strikes, poisoning, feral dogs, illegal poaching, and occasional outbreaks of [[feline leukemia]].<ref name=efe091003 /> Chronic renal illness affects some captive animals.<ref name=rtve100326 /> Habitat loss is due mainly to infrastructure improvement, urban and resort development and tree monocultivation, which fragments the lynx's distribution. In the 20th century, rabbit diseases such as [[myxomatosis]] and [[Rabbit haemorrhagic disease|hemorrhagic disease]] resulted in a dramatic decline of its main prey;<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/12/14-0517_article|title=Ecosystem Effects of Variant Rabbit Hemorrhagic Disease Virus, Iberian Peninsula|first1=Miguel|last1=Delibes-Mateos|first2=Catarina|last2=Ferreira|first3=Francisco|last3=Carro|first4=Marco A.|last4=Escudero|first5=Christian|last5=Gort√°zar|publisher=|journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases|volume=20|issue=12|pages=2166‚Äì2168|doi=10.3201/eid2012.140517|pmid=25417710|pmc=4257825}}</ref> outbreaks have been reported into the 2010s.<ref name=efe130917 /> Accidental vehicle strikes are the leading cause of unnatural death;<ref name=materia131205 /><ref name=ep130911 /> The death toll on Spanish roads was 14 in 2013,<ref name=EFE140101 /> and 21 in 2014.{{r|Pais150219}} Illegal traps set for rabbits and foxes are other leading causes for lynx fatality.{{r|BC1992}}
In 2013, it was reported that the Iberian lynx possesses antibiotic resistant bacteria within its digestive tract, which may lead to more dangerous and difficult-to-treat infections and decrease the cat's fitness.{{r|TE2013}} A 2013 study suggests climate change may threaten the Iberian lynx species due to their inability to adapt well to new climates or it may lead them to relocate to areas that have a more suitable climate but fewer rabbits, increasing mortality.{{r|NCC2013}}
Management efforts are being developed to conserve and restore the animal's native range.<ref name=Clavero2013>{{cite journal |last1=Clavero |first1=M. |last2=Delibes |first2=M. |year=2013 |title=Using historical accounts to set conservation baselines: the case of Lynx species in Spain |journal=Biodiversity Conservation Journal |volume=22 |issue=8 |pages=1691‚Äì1702 |doi=10.1007/s10531-013-0506-4}}</ref> Officials intending to release captive-bred lynx look for areas of appropriate habitat, rabbit abundance, and acceptance by the local human population.<ref name=NL130621 /> About 90 million euros was spent on various conservation measures between 1994 and 2013.<ref name=UA130722 /> The [[European Union]] contributes up to 61% of funding.<ref name=elpais131215 /><ref name=efe091003 />
[[File:Linces10.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Iberian lynx in closeup]]
=== Wild population and re-introductions === [[File:Poblaci√≥n lince.jpg|thumb|left|Graph showing Iberian lynx population in Spain, 1960‚Äì2007]]
The Iberian lynx species has declined by about 80% in the last 20 years. The cat was estimated to number 3,000 in 1960,<ref name=SOSlynx /> about 400 in 2000, less than 200 in 2002, and possibly as few as 100 in March 2005.<ref name=bbc050310 /> [[Do√±ana National Park]] and the Sierra de [[And√∫jar]], [[Ja√©n (Spanish province)|Ja√©n]] had the only known breeding populations until the 2007 discovery of a previously unknown population of around 15 individuals in [[Castile-La Mancha]] (central [[Spain]]).<ref name=sd0710 /><ref name=deshok /> In 2008, the Do√±ana population was assessed at 24 to 33, while the [[Sierra Morena]] group was believed to number 67 to 190 adults. The total population was estimated to be 99 to 158 adults, including the La Mancha population. The Iberian lynx was thus listed as Critically Endangered under C2a(i) on the IUCN Redlist.<ref name=iucn />
Beginning in 2009, the Iberian lynx was reintroduced into [[Embalse de Guadalmellato|Guadalmellato]], resulting in a population of 23 in 2013.<ref name=eleco130408 /> Since 2010, the species has also been released in Guarrizas.<ref name=NL130621 /><ref name=decpaper /> Discussions were held with the Ministry of Environment on plans for releases in the Campanarios de Azaba area near [[Salamanca]].<ref name=rewild /> In April 2013, it was reported that Andalusia's total wild population‚Äîonly 94 in 2002‚Äîhad tripled to 309 individuals.<ref name=elmundo130409 /><ref name=eleco130408 /> In July 2013, environmental groups confirmed the presence of a wild-born litter in the [[Province of C√°ceres]] ([[Extremadura]]).<ref name=efe130706 /> A study published in July 2013 in ''Nature Climate Change'' advised that reintroduction programs take place in northern Iberia, suggesting that climate change would threaten rabbits in the south.<ref name=UA130722 /><ref name=LS130721 />
On 26 November 2014, 8 Iberian lynxes were released into [[Toledo, Spain]]; one of them traveled near [[Madrid]], the first time in 40 years.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://elpais.com/elpais/2015/03/09/inenglish/1425900807_150674.html|title= Iberian Lynx returns to Madrid region after 40 years|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 10 March 2015|website= |publisher= El Pais}}</ref>
The presence of Iberian lynxes in Portugal, particularly in the south, has been verified.<ref name=pu130601 /> In 2014, the [[Institute for Nature Conservation and Forests]] signed contracts securing 2,000 hectares of land for Portugal's reintroduction project.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lynx pardinas (2000)|url=http://www.icnf.pt/portal/naturaclas/rn2000/resource/docs/rn-plan-set/mamif/lynx-pardinus/|website=ICNF Portal|publisher=ICN:B|accessdate=27 June 2017|language=Portuguese}}</ref><ref>http://www.icnf.pt/portal/naturaclas/rn2000/resource/docs/rn-plan-set/mamif/lynx-pardinus/</ref><ref name=PN141113 /> On 16 December 2014, a pair of Iberian lynx was released into [[Guadiana Valley Natural Park]] near [[M√©rtola]], Portugal.{{r|PN141218}} On 7 February 2015, another pair was released into the park, but the female was later found dead on 12 March 2015 after being poisoned in M√©rtola.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.theportugalnews.com/news/iberian-lynx-female-released-last-month-found-dead/34313|title= Iberian Lynx female released last month found dead|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 19 March 2015|website= |publisher= The Portugal News}}</ref> The last pair of captive-bred Iberian lynxes were released into Guadiana Valley Nature Reserve on 12 May 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.theportugalnews.com/news/final-two-iberian-lynx-released-into-the-wild/34765|title= Final two Iberian Lynx released into the wild|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 14 May 2015|website= theportugalnews.com|publisher= The Portugal News}}</ref> By the end of 2015 there were 400 lynx on the Iberian peninsula, the vast majority in Andalusia, in southern Spain, but with smaller new populations in the hills near Toledo, in Extremadura (south-western Spain) and in southern Portugal.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-35890789|title=The return of the lynx|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=28 March 2016|website=bbc.com|publisher=BBC|access-date=12 April 2016}}</ref>
The reintroduction of Iberian lynx in Portugal has been a success; from 17 animals that were reintroduced, 12 have already established territories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wilder.pt/historias/comecou-hoje-a-epoca-de-2017-de-libertacoes-de-linces-em-portugal/|title=Come√ßou a √©poca de 2017 de liberta√ß√µes de linces em Portugal|date=17 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
Since a 2007 outbreak of [[feline leukemia virus]] (FeLV), wild lynxes are tested periodically for possible disease. September‚ÄìDecember 2013 samples were negative for FeLV but one male became the first of his species to test positive for [[feline immunodeficiency virus]] (FIV) and was placed into quarantine.<ref name=EP131230 />
=== Captive breeding === [[File:Iberian Lynx CNRLI reproduction centre 10 May 2015 (15).JPG|thumb|right|250px|The Iberian Lynx CNRLI reproduction centre near the village of Vale Fuzeiros near the town of [[Silves, Portugal]]]] In 2002, the Jerez Zoo confirmed it had three females and was developing a plan for a captive breeding program.<ref name=guard0204 /> One of those females was [[Saliega]], captured as a kitten in April 2002.<ref name=guard0204 /> She became the first Iberian lynx to breed in captivity, giving birth to three healthy kittens on 29 March 2005 at the El Acebuche Breeding Center, in the Do√±ana Nature Park in [[Huelva]], Spain.<ref name=bbc050330 /> Over the following years, the number of births grew and additional breeding centers were opened. In March 2009, it was reported that 27 kittens had been born since the beginning of the program.<ref name=ap090320 /> In 2009, the Spanish government planned to build a ‚Ç¨5.5 million breeding center in [[Zarza de Granadilla]].<ref name=ap090320 /> In Portugal the Centro Nacional de Reprodu√ß√£o do Lince-Ib√©rico (CNRLI) established a breeding center in [[Silves, Portugal|Silves]].<ref name=TPN130627 /><ref name=expr130402 />
There were 14 surviving kittens in 2008 and 15 in 2009.<ref name=rtve100818 /> In 2010, intense rain and health issues resulted in lower reproductive success‚Äî14 born, 8 surviving<ref name=rtve100818 />‚Äîbut the next year, breeding centers recorded 45 births with 26 surviving kittens.<ref name=ep120617 /> In 2012, breeding centers in Portugal and Spain reported a total of 44 survivors from 59 births,<ref name=ep120617 /><ref name=tpn120331 /> while 2013 saw a total of 44 survivors out of 53 born.<ref name=efe130909 /> In 2017, the total population of Iberian lynx reached 475 specimens.<ref>{{cite web|title=El lince ib√©rico ampl√≠a sus dominios y alcanza los 475 ejemplares, pese a la falta de conejos y los atropellos|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/natural/20170202/413902666216/lince.html|publisher=La Vanguardia|accessdate=11 July 2017}}</ref>
In March 2013, it was reported that Iberian lynx embryos and oocytes had been collected and preserved for the first time.<ref name=fvb130323 /> They were collected from Saliega and another female‚Äîboth sterilized and retired from the breeding program‚Äîby Berlin's Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research and stored in liquid nitrogen at the [[Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales]] in Madrid for possible future breeding.<ref name=fvb130323 /> In July 2014, the MNCN-CSIC announced they had produced sperm cells from the testicular tissue of sexually immature lynx.<ref name=mundo140722 />
Iberian lynx can be observed in captivity only at the Jerez Zoo,<ref name=zoobotanico2014 /> since December 2014 at the [[Lisbon Zoo]],<ref name=observador211214 /> and since July 2016 at the [[Madrid Zoo]].<ref name=zoomadrid200716 /> The [[Jerez de la Frontera|Jerez]] animals integrate the breeding program, the two Lisbon lynxes were formerly in the Portuguese breeding center but are no longer suited for the program (the female had multiple failed pregnancies and the male has a form of epilepsy),<ref name=ultimoreduto17032015 /> and the two Madrid lynxes were equally retired from the breeding program for not being suited for reproduction.
== Genetic studies == In August 2012, researchers announced that the genome of the Iberian lynx had been sequenced.<ref name=mat120808 /> They also plan genetic testing of the remains of long-deceased lynx to quantify loss of genetic diversity and improve conservation programs.<ref name=mat121231 /> In December 2012, it was reported that researchers had located remains of 466 Iberian lynx in private and museum collections.<ref name=mat121231 /> However, it is estimated that 40% of specimens were lost over the preceding 20 years.<ref name=mat121231 />
Genetic diversity in the Iberian lynx is lower than in any other felids known to be genetically impoverished, including the [[cheetah]] (''Acinonyx jubatus''), Ngorongoro crater lions, and Scandinavia's Eurasian lynx. Researchers believe this may be a consequence of decreasing population sizes and isolation.{{r|Casas2013}} A study published in 2013 indicated strong genetic differentiation between the Do√±ana and Andujar populations, due to both allelic frequencies and allelic composition. Do√±ana lynxes have differentiated more from the ancestral population as a result of their longer isolation and lower population size. The researchers suggested bringing the two groups together in order to lessen the degree of inbreeding.<ref name=Casas2013>{{cite journal |journal= [[Molecular Ecology]] |title= Genetics at the verge of extinction: insights from the Iberian lynx |author= Casas-Marce, M. |author2= Soriano, L. |author3= L√≥pez-Bao, J. V. |author4= Godoy, J. A. |last-author-amp= yes |year= 2013 |doi= 10.1111/mec.12498 |volume=22 |issue= 22 |pages=5503‚Äì5515}}</ref>

{{Infobox Book | name = Infinite Worlds: An Illustrated Voyage to Planets Beyond Our Sun | image = | image_caption = | author = Ray Villard and Lynette Cook | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] | genre = Nonfiction | publisher = | release_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = }} '''''Infinite Worlds: An Illustrated Voyage to Planets Beyond Our Sun''''' is a nonfiction book by Ray Villard and Lynette Cook about [[extrasolar planets]], featuring Lynette Cook's artwork. The book covers topics from the Big Bang, to extrasolar planets (the main focus of the book), and the [[ultimate fate of the universe]]. From the book's description on the back cover:
The newly discovered planets are boggling astronomers' minds with their bizarre characteristics, including an unimagined diversity of sizes and orbits. In Lynette Cook's illustrations - many newly created for this book - we glimpse the landscapes and atmospheres that might adorn these planets. Ray Villard's text describes the state of astronomy today, imagines where it will take us in the coming years, ponders the chances of success for the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI), and explores the survivability of life in the context of an evolving and accelerating universe. Infinite Worlds is a cosmic adventure that brings the drama of creation and the beauty of the universe to anyone who has wondered at the night sky

{{Infobox royalty |consort=yes | title =John Fulton | name = | full name =John Fulton | image =John Fulton Memorial Hall, Fenwick.JPG | caption = The John Fulton Memorial Hall | reign = | spouse = | issue = | issue-link =#Issue | issue-pipe =More | house = | royal anthem = | father = | mother = | birth_date = 1803 | birth_place = [[Fenwick, East Ayrshire|Fenwick]], East Ayrshire, Scotland | death_date = 1853 | death_place =[[Fenwick, East Ayrshire|Fenwick]], East Ayrshire, Scotland. | place of burial=[[Fenwick, East Ayrshire|Fenwick]], East Ayrshire, Scotland. |}}
'''John Fulton''' (1803–1853), was originally a cobbler or [[Shoemaking|shoemaker]] by trade.<ref name=fw>[http://thefenwickweavers.coop/fenwick-in-history/john-fulton/ Fenwick Weavers] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915031438/http://thefenwickweavers.coop/fenwick-in-history/john-fulton/# |date=2013-09-15 }} Retrieved : 2012-07-24</ref> He built three [[orrery]]s in a workshop attached to at his home, now demolished, in the [[Kirton Brae]] area of [[Fenwick, East Ayrshire|Fenwick]]<ref>Love, Page 102</ref> and was eventually appointed [[Musical instrument|instrument]] maker to King [[William IV of the United Kingdom|William IV]], moving to London, but retiring to [[Fenwick, East Ayrshire|Fenwick]]. He is buried in the Fenwick Kirk graveyard.<ref name=fw/>
==Life== It is recorded that John's father, also a cobbler, was a subscribing member to the library set up in the village by the Fenwick Weavers. With access to this library, John pursued his interest in astronomy, mathematics, physics, and other disciplines that led to his career as an instrument maker of outstanding ability and achievement.<ref name=fw/><ref>Adamson, Page 120</ref> Largely self-taught, he studied botany, learned several foreign languages, constructed a ‚Äòvelocipede‚Äô or early bicycle, and experimented with the production of coal gas. He had left school at the age of only thirteen.
===Orrerys=== [[File:Fenwick Parish Church - east side.JPG|thumb|200px|left|Fenwick Kirk, burial place of John Fulton.]] [[Astronomy]] held a particular fascination for him, so much so that he was prompted to construct, in his spare time in the years between 1823 and 1833, three working models of the solar system, known as orrerys.<ref>[http://futuremuseum.co.uk/Collection.aspx/john_fulton/Description Future Museum]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Retrieved : 2012-07-24</ref> The third of these is now on display in Glasgow's [[Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum]]: it was the most intricate and took him four years to finish. It measured 1000mm x 3000mm x 3000mm. Entirely his own work, it has 175 wheels and more than 200 moving parts and is acknowledged to be one of the best in the world.<ref>[http://collections.glasgowmuseums.com/starobject.html?oid=386785 Glasgow Museums] Retrieved : 2012-07-24</ref> The Society of Arts, who awarded him a silver medal,<ref>[https://archive.is/20121211060400/http://hausman27.wordpress.com/2011/12/04/intellectual-icon-john-fultons-orrery/ Intellectual Icons] Retrieved : 2012-07-24</ref> calculated that his third orrery was the most perfect built up to that time.<ref>Love, Page 103</ref>
Fulton took the orrery on a tour of the United Kingdom. Such was the public interest that in 1869 a group of Glasgow businessmen led by William Walker bought the orrery for the city. It was brought up from London and then toured around Glasgow schools and museums until the 1930s when it found a more permanent home in the Old Glasgow Museum.<ref>[http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image.php?inum=TGSE00101&t=2&urltp=search.php%3Fstart%3D0%26end%3D20%26what%3D%26where%3D|yorkhill%26who%3D%26period%3D0%26collection%3D0%26search%3D99 The Glasgow Story] Retrieved : 2012-07-24</ref>
A local story relates that Fulton 'borrowed' his grandmother‚Äôs candlesticks and melted them down to provide the brass for his first orrery model.<ref name=fw/>
==John Fulton Memorial Hall== This is the public meeting hall for Fenwick, maintained by [[East Ayrshire Council]]. It was previously the Guthrie Memorial Free Church of 1844,<ref>Adamson, Page 107</ref> and following a worldwide fund raising campaign sufficient funds had been raised by 1919 and the hall was opened in 1920.<ref name=fw/>
==References== ;Notes {{refbegin}} {{reflist|2}} {{refend}}
:Sources {{refbegin}} # Adamson, Archibald R. (1875). ''Rambles Round Kilmarnock''. Kilmarnock : T. Stevenson. # Love, Dane (2003). ''Ayrshire : Discovering a County''. Ayr : Fort Publishing. {{ISBN|0-9544461-1-9}}. {{refend}}
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2PGSSwZdGm4 John Fulton of Fenwick and Orrery Models] * {{YouTube|5Iu8XDpPs-I|3D Orrery Model}} * [https://archive.is/20121211060400/http://hausman27.wordpress.com/2011/12/04/intellectual-icon-john-fultons-orrery/ Intellectual Icons]

In artificial intelligence, knowledge-based agents draw on a pool of logical sentences to infer conclusions about the [[world]]. At the '''knowledge level''', we only need to specify what the agent knows and what its goals are; a logical abstraction separate from details of implementation.
This notion of knowledge level was first introduced by [[Allen Newell]] in the 1980s, to have a way to rationalize an agent's behavior. The agent takes actions based on knowledge it possesses, in an attempt to reach specific goals. It chooses actions according to the [[principle of rationality]].
Beneath the knowledge level resides the [[symbol level]]. Whereas the knowledge level is ''world'' oriented, namely that it concerns the environment in which the agent operates, the symbol level is ''system'' oriented, in that it includes the mechanisms the agent has available to operate. The knowledge level ''rationalizes'' the agent's behavior, while the symbol level ''mechanizes'' the agent's behavior.
For example, in a computer program, the knowledge level consists of the information contained in its data structures that it uses to perform certain actions. The symbol level consists of the program's algorithms, the data structures themselves, and so on.
==See also==
*[[Knowledge level modeling]] *[[knowledge relativity]]
==References== *A. Lieto, C. Lebiere, A. Oltramari. The Knowledge Level in Cognitive Architectures: Current Limitations and Possible Developments, Cognitive Systems Research, 48:39-55, 2018. *T. Menzies. Applications of Abduction: Knowledge-Level Modeling. November 1996. *A. Newell. The Knowledge Level. Artificial Intelligence, 18(1):87-127, 1982.

{{Infobox park | name = Lewis and Clark Landing | photo = LewisandClarkLandingOmaha.jpg | photo_width = 300 | photo_caption = Lewis and Clark Landing along the [[Missouri River]]. | type = Municipal ([[City of Omaha Department of Parks, Recreation, and Public Property|Omaha]]) | location = [[Downtown Omaha]] | coords = | area = {{convert|23|acre|ha}} | created = 2003 | operator = | visitation_num = | status = Open all year }} '''Lewis and Clark Landing''' is a public park located at 515 North Riverfront Drive in [[Downtown Omaha, Nebraska]] . This {{convert|23|acre|ha|adj=on}} park is situated along the eight-foot-tall (2.4 m) river walk of the [[Missouri River]] just north of [[Interstate 480 (Iowa-Nebraska)|U.S. Interstate 480]].
== History == Lewis and Clark Landing is the original landing site of the 1804 [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]]. The Lewis and Clark Expedition took place from 1804 to 1806. The purpose of the expedition was to explore the land which the [[United States]] had purchased from [[France]] through the [[Louisiana Purchase]] in 1803. Lewis and Clark Landing now sits on property formerly owned by [[ASARCO]], which maintained a lead refinery there that closed in 1997. [[HDR Inc.]] won an award from the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] for their work on remediation of the Lewis and Clark Landing.<ref>[http://www.hdrinc.com/about-hdr/news-and-events/news-releases/2009-11-18-hdr-designed-asarco-remediation-project-wins-phoe "HDR-designed ASARCO remediation project wins Phoenix award," HDR website. Retrieved 9/25/10.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711155626/http://www.hdrinc.com/about-hdr/news-and-events/news-releases/2009-11-18-hdr-designed-asarco-remediation-project-wins-phoe |date=2011-07-11 }}</ref>
== Features ==
The park has a number of distinct features including as a walking trail which follows the riverfront and a bike trail which takes riders west to [[River City Star|Miller's Landing]] and another trail which leads to the [[Heartland of America Park]]. The [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] Pedestrian Bridge, with interpretive exhibits, connects to [[CenturyLink Center Omaha]]. The park also includes the Omaha Firefighter's Memorial Monument and the second largest labor monument in the United States. The park contains a walking trail which follows the riverfront and sections of a bike trail that connect to Omaha's bike trail system. The walking trail also connects to the [[Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge]] that spans the river and joins Omaha with [[Council Bluffs]], [[Iowa]]. There is expansive area for festivals and events and there are a number of tables with umbrellas and chairs that offer a chance to relax and take in the riverfront experience. Additional attractions include a "Monument to Labor" sculpture, Lewis and Clark interpretive exhibits, jumping fountains where children can play, and a historical marker on site.<ref>[http://www.visitomaha.com/listings/index.cfm?action=displayListing&listingID=57383 "Lewis & Clark Landing"], Omaha Convention and Visitor's Bureau. Retrieved 8/28/10.</ref><ref>[http://www.visitnebraska.gov/component/myplanner/detail/63/2000608 "Lewis and Clark Landing"], Nebraska Tourism Bureau. Retrieved 8/28/10.</ref>
The park is immediately down the trail from Omaha's new National Park Service Regional Headquarters. The office houses the superintendent of the [[Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail]].<ref>Gale, K. [http://mouthoftheplatte.org/lclandingstory.htm "New mouth of the Platte chapter in political contest over naming riverfront plaza in Omaha, Nebraska 'Lewis and Clark Landing'"], Mouth of the Platte. Retrieved 8/28/10.</ref>
==Entertainment== Every summer the Landing and Heartland of America Park host a free concert series. The Annual Playing with Fire concerts began in 2004.

revision.text:
[[File:1aoi nucleosome rib round.tif|thumb|right| Nucleosome X-ray crystal structure]] Crystal structures of protein and nucleic acid molecules and their complexes are central to the practice of most parts of [[biophysics]], and have shaped much of what we understand scientifically at the atomic-detail level of biology. Their importance is underlined by the United Nations declaring 2014 as the [[International Year of Crystallography]], as the 100th anniversary of [[Max von Laue]]'s 1914 [[Nobel prize]] for discovering the [[diffraction]] of X-rays by crystals. This chronological list of biophysically notable protein and nucleic acid structures is loosely based on a review in the [[Biophysical Journal]].<ref name=BJ>{{cite journal |vauthors=Richardson JS, Richardson DC |title=Biophysical highlights from 54 years of macromolecular crystallography |journal=Biophysical Journal |year=2014 |volume=106 |pages=510‚Äì525 |doi=10.1016/j.bpj.2014.01.001 |pmid=24507592 |pmc=3945011}}</ref> The list includes all the first dozen distinct structures, those that broke new ground in subject or method, and those that became model systems for work in future biophysical areas of research.
==Myoglobin== [[File:Myoglobin helix cylinder sketch.jpg|thumb|left|140px| Myoglobin sketch]] [[File:Helix electron density myoglobin 2nrl 17-32.jpg|thumb|right|80px| Alpha helix]] 1960 - '''[[Myoglobin]]''' was the very first high-resolution crystal structure of a protein molecule.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kendrew JC, Dickerson RE, Strandberg BE, Davies DR, Phillips DC, Shore VC |title=Structure of myoglobin: A three-dimensional Fourier synthesis at 2√Ö resolution |year=1960 |journal=Nature |volume=185 |pages=422‚Äì427 |doi=10.1038/185422a0 |pmid=18990802 |issue=4711}}</ref> Myoglobin cradles an iron-containing [[heme]] group that reversibly binds oxygen for use in powering [[muscle]] fibers, and those first crystals were of myoglobin from the [[sperm whale]], whose muscles need copious oxygen storage for deep dives. The myoglobin 3-dimensional structure is made up of 8 [[alpha helix|alpha-helices]], and the crystal structure showed that their conformation was right-handed and very closely matched the geometry proposed by [[Linus Pauling]], with 3.6 residues per turn and backbone hydrogen bonds from the peptide NH of one residue to the peptide CO of residue i+4. Myoglobin is a model system for many types of biophysical studies,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Frauenfelder H, McMahon BH, Fenimore PW |title=Myoglobin: the hydrogen atom of biology and a paradigm of complexity |year=2003 |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences USA |volume=100 |pages=8615‚Äì8617 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1633688100|pmc=166357 }}</ref> especially involving the binding process of small ligands such as [[oxygen]] and [[carbon monoxide]].
==Hemoglobin== [[File:Hemoglobin beta red whBkg.tif|thumb|left| 160px| Hemoglobin beta chain]] [[File:Hemoglobin t-r state ani.gif|thumb|right| Hemoglobin oxy/deoxy transition]] 1960 - The '''[[Hemoglobin]]''' crystal structure<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Perutz MF, Rossmann MG, Cullis AF, Muirhead H, North AC |title=Structure of haemoglobin: A three-dimensional Fourier synthesis at 5.5-√Ö resolution, obtained by X-ray analysis |year=1960 |journal=Nature |volume=185 |pages=416‚Äì422 |doi=10.1038/185416a0 |pmid=18990801 |issue=4711}}</ref> showed a tetramer of two related chain types and was solved at much lower resolution than the monomeric myoglobin, but it clearly had the same basic 8-helix architecture (now called the "globin fold"). Further hemoglobin crystal structures at higher resolution [PDB 1MHB, 1DHB) soon showed the coupled change of both local and [[Quaternary structure|quaternary conformation]] between the oxy and deoxy states of hemoglobin,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Perutz MF |title=Stereochemistry of Cooperative Effects in Haemoglobin: Haem‚ÄìHaem Interaction and the Problem of Allostery |year=1970 |journal=Nature |volume=228 |pages=726‚Äì734 |doi=10.1038/228726a0 |issue=5273}}</ref> which explains the cooperativity of oxygen binding in the blood and the [[allostery|allosteric]] effect of factors such as [[pH]] and [[2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate|DPG]]. For decades hemoglobin was the primary teaching example for the concept of allostery, as well as being an intensive focus of research and discussion on allostery. In 1909, hemoglobin crystals from >100 species were used to relate taxonomy to molecular properties.<ref name=Reichert>{{cite book |author1=Edward Tyson Reichert |author2=Amos Peaslee Brown |lastauthoramp=yes|title=The Differentiation and Specificity of Corresponding Proteins and other Vital Substances in Relation to Biological Classification and Organic Evolution: The Crystallography of Hemoglobins |year=1909 |publisher=Carnegie Institution |location=Washington, DC}}</ref> That book was cited by [[Max Perutz|Perutz]] in the 1938 report<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bernal JD, Fankuchen I, Perutz M |title=X-ray syudy of chymotrypsin and hemoglobin |year=1938 |journal=Nature |volume=141 |pages=523‚Äì524|doi=10.1038/141523a0 }}</ref> of horse hemoglobin crystals that began his long saga to solve the crystal structure. Hemoglobin crystals are [[pleochroism|pleochroic]] - dark red in two directions and pale red in the third<ref name=Reichert/> - because of the orientation of the hemes, and the bright [[Soret peak|Soret band]] of the heme [[porphyrin]] groups is used in spectroscopic analysis of hemoglobin ligand binding.
[[File:HEW lysozyme rib bw.tif|thumb|left|160px| HEW lysozyme ribbon]]
==Hen-egg-white lysozyme== 1965 - '''Hen-egg-white [[lysozyme]]''' (PDB file 1lyz).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Blake CC, Koenig DF, Mair GA, North AC, Phillips DC, Sarma VR |title=Structure of hen egg-white lysozyme: A three-dimensional Fourier synthesis at 2√Ö resolution |year=1965 |journal=Nature |volume=206 |pages=757‚Äì761 |doi=10.1038/206757a0 |pmid=5891407 |issue=4986}}</ref> was the first crystal structure of an enzyme (it cleaves small [[carbohydrates]] into simple sugars), used for early studies of enzyme mechanism.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Warshel A, Levitt M |title=Theoretical studies of enzymic reactions: Dielectric, electrostatic, and steric stabilization of the carbonium ion in the reaction of lysozyme |year=1976 |journal=J Mol Biol |volume=103 |pages=227‚Äì49|pmid=985660 |doi=10.1016/0022-2836(76)90311-9}}</ref> It contained [[beta sheet]] (antiparallel) as well as helices, and was also the first macromolecular structure to have its atomic coordinates refined (in real space).<ref>{{cite journal |author=Diamond R |title=Real-space refinement of the structure of hen egg-white lysozyme |year=1974 |journal=Journal of Molecular Biology |volume= 82 |pages=371‚Äì374 |doi=10.1016/0022-2836(74)90598-1}}</ref> The starting material for preparation can be bought at the grocery store, and hen-egg lysozyme crystallizes very readily in many different [[space groups]]; it is the favorite test case for new crystallographic experiments and instruments. Recent examples are nanocrystals of lysozyme for free-electron laser data collection<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Boutet S, Lomb L, Williams GJ, etal |title=High-resolution protein structure determination by serial femtosecond crystallography |year=2012 |journal=Science |volume=337 |pages=362‚Äì364|doi=10.1126/science.1217737 |url=http://bib-pubdb1.desy.de/record/140575/files/lysozyme-all.pdf }}</ref> and microcrystals for micro electron diffraction.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Shi D, Nannenga BL, Iadenza MG, Gonen T |title=Three-dimensional electron crystallography of protein microcrystals |year=2013 |journal=eLife |volume=2 |pages=e01345-e01345 |doi=10.7554/elife.01345}}</ref>
[[File:RibonucleaseA SS paleRib.png|thumb|right|180px| Ribonuclease A ribbon drawing]]
==Ribonuclease== 1967 - '''[[Ribonuclease A]]''' (PDB file 2RSA)<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kartha G, Bello J, Harker D |title=Tertiary structure of ribonuclease |year=1967 |journal=Nature |volume=213 |pages=862‚Äì865 |doi=10.1038/213862a0 |pmid=6043657 |issue=5079}}</ref> is an RNA-cleaving enzyme stabilized by 4 disulfide bonds. It was used in [[Christian B. Anfinsen|Anfinsen]]'s seminal research on protein folding which led to the concept that a protein's 3-dimensional structure was determined by its [[amino-acid]] sequence. [[Ribonuclease S]], the cleaved, two-component form studied by [[Frederic M. Richards|Fred Richards]], was also enzymatically active, had a nearly identical crystal structure (PDB file 1RNS),<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wyckoff HW, Hardman KD, Allewell NM, Inagami T, Johnson LN, Richards FM |title=The structure of ribonuclease-S at 3.5 √Ö resolution |year=1967 |journal=Journal of Biological Chemistry |volume=242 |pages=3984‚Äì3988}}</ref> and was shown to be catalytically active even in the crystal,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Doscher MS, Richards FM | year=1963| title=The activity of an enzyme in the crystalline state: Ribonuclease-S| journal=Journal of Biological Chemistry| volume=238| pages=2399‚Äì2406}}</ref> helping dispel doubts about the relevance of protein crystal structures to biological function.
[[File:Elastase ribbon BW.jpg|thumb|left|160px| Two domains of elastase]]
==Serine proteases== 1967 - The [[serine proteases]] are a historically very important group of enzyme structures, because collectively they illuminated catalytic mechanism (in their case, by the Ser-His-Asp "catalytic triad"), the basis of differing substrate specificities, and the activation mechanism by which a controlled enzymatic cleavage buries the new chain end to properly rearrange the active site.<ref>{{cite book |vauthors=Dickerson RE, Geis I |title=Structure and Action of Proteins |year=1969 |publisher= Harper |location=New York}}</ref> The early crystal structures included '''[[chymotrypsin]] '''(PDB file 2CHA),<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Matthews BW, Sigler PB, Henderson R, Blow DM |title=Three-dimensional structure of tosyl-Œ±-chymotrypsin |year=1967 |journal=Nature |volume=214 |pages=652‚Äì656 |doi=10.1038/214652a0 |issue=5089}}</ref> '''[[chymotrypsinogen]]''' (PDB file 1CHG),<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Freer ST, Kraut J, Robertus JD, Tonle H, Wright HT |title=Chymotrypsinogen: 2.5-√Ö crystal structure, comparison with Œ±-chymotrypsin, and implications for zymogen activation |year=1970 |journal= Biochemistry |volume=9 |pages=1997‚Äì2009 |doi=10.1021/bi00811a022 |pmid=5442169 |issue=9}}</ref> '''[[trypsin]]''' (PDB file 1PTN),<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fehlhammer H, Bode W |title=The refined crystal structure of bovine beta-trypsin at 1.8√Ö resolution, II. Crystallographic refinement, calcium binding site and active site at pH 7.0 |year=1975 |journal=Journal of Molecular Biology |volume=98 |pages=693‚Äì697|doi=10.1016/s0022-2836(75)80005-2 }}</ref> and '''[[elastase]]''' (PDB file 1EST).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sawyer L, Shotton DM, Campbell JW, Ladner RC |title=The atomic structure of crystalline porcine pancreatic elastase at 2.5√Ö resolution: comparison with the structure of alpha-chymotrypsin |year=1978 |journal=Journal of Molecular Biology |volume=118 |pages=137‚Äì208 |doi=10.1016/0022-2836(78)90412-6}}</ref> They also were the first protein structures that showed two near-identical domains, presumably related by [[gene duplication]]. One reason for their wide use as textbook and classroom examples was the insertion-code numbering system (hated by all computer programmers), which made Ser195 and His57 consistent and memorable despite the protein-specific sequence differences.
==Papain== 1968 - '''[[Papain]]'''
[[File:Carboxypeptidase-A rib bw.tif|thumb|left|160px| Carboxypeptidase, with Zn]] [[File:Potato CPA inhibitor ribbon.jpg|thumb|right|120px| CPA inhibitor]]
==Carboxypeptidase== 1969 - '''[[Carboxypeptidase A]]''' is a zinc [[metalloprotease]]. Its crystal structure (PDB file 1CPA)<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Lipscomb WN |author2=Hartsuck JA |author3=Reeke GN |author4=Quiocho FA |author5=Bethge PH |author6=Ludwif=g ML |author7=Steitz TA |author8=Muirhead H |author9=Coppola JC |title= The structure of carboxypeptidase A, VII. The 2.0-√Ö resolution studies of the enzyme and of its complex with glycyltyrosine, and mechanistic deductions |year=1969 |journal=Brookhaven Symposia in Biology |volume= 21 |pages=24‚Äì90}}</ref> showed the first parallel beta structure: a large, twisted, central sheet of 8 strands with the active-site Zn located at the C-terminal end of the middle strands and the sheet flanked on both sides with alpha helices. It is an [[exopeptidase]] that cleaves peptides or proteins from the carboxy-terminal end rather than internal to the sequence. Later a small protein inhibitor of carboxypeptidase was solved (PDB file 4CPA)<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rees DC, Lipscomb WN |title=Refined crystal structure of the potato inhibitor complex of carboxypeptidase A at 2.5 A resolution |year=1982 |journal=Journal of Molecular Biology |volume=160 |pages=475‚Äì498 |doi=10.1016/0022-2836(82)90309-6}}</ref> that mechanically stops the catalysis by presenting its C-terminal end just sticking out from between a ring of disulfide bonds with tight structure behind it, preventing the enzyme from sucking in the chain past the first residue.
==Subtilisin== 1969 - '''[[Subtilisin]]'''
==Lactate dehydrogenase== 1970 - '''[[Lactate dehydrogenase]]'''
==Trypsin inhibitor== 1970 - '''Basic pancreatic [[trypsin inhibitor]]''', or BPTI,
==Rubredoxin== 1970 - '''[[Rubredoxin]]''' [[File:Insulin worm bw.jpg|thumb|left|160px| SS-linked insulin monomer]] [[File:Insulincrystals.jpg|thumb|right|140px| Space-grown insulin crystals]]
==Insulin== 1971 - '''[[Insulin]]''' (PDB file 1INS)<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Blundell TL, Cutfield JF, Cutfield SM, Dodson EJ, Dodson GG, Hodgkin DC, Mercola DA, Vijayan M |title=Atomic positions in rhombohedral 2-zinc insulin crystals |year=1971 |journal=Nature |volume=231 |pages=506‚Äì511 |doi=10.1038/231506a0 |pmid=4932997 |issue=5304}}</ref> is a [[hormone]] central to the [[metabolism]] of sugar and fat storage, and important in human diseases such as [[obesity]] and [[diabetes]]. It is biophysically notable for its Zn binding, its equilibrium between monomer, dimer, and hexamer states, its ability to form crystals in vivo, and its synthesis as a longer "pro" form which is then cleaved to fold up as the active 2-chain, SS-linked monomer. Insulin was a success of [[NASA]]'s crystal-growth program on the [[space shuttle]], producing bulk preparations of very uniform tiny crystals for controlled dosage.

==Vault particle== 2009 The '''[[Vault (organelle)|Vault particle]]''' is an intriguing new discovery of a large hollow particle common in cells, with several different suggestions for its possible biological function. The crystal structures (PDB files 2zuo, 2zv4, 2zv5<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tanaka H, Kato K, Yamashita E, Sumizawa T, Zhou Y, Yau M, Iwasaki K, Yoshimura M, Tsukihara T |title=The Structure of Rat Liver Vault at 3.5 Angstrom Resolution |year=2009 |journal=Science |volume=323 |pages=384‚Äì388 |doi=10.1126/science.1164975 |pmid=19150846 |issue=5912}}</ref> and 4hl8<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Casanas A, Querol-Audi J, Guerra P, Pous J, Tanaka H, Tsukihara T, Verdaguer N, Fita I |title=New features of vault architecture and dynamics revealed by novel refinement using the deformable elastic network approach |year=2013 |journal=Acta Crystallographica |volume=D69 |pages=1054‚Äì1061 |pmid=23695250 |doi=10.1107/S0907444913004472 |issue=Pt 6}}</ref>) show that each half of the vault is made up of 39 copies of a long 12-domain protein that swirl together to form the enclosure. Disorder at the very top and bottom ends suggests openings for possible access to the interior of the vault.

The following is a partial '''list of scientific journals'''. There are thousands of [[scientific journal]]s in publication, and many more have been published at various points in the past. The list given here is far from exhaustive, only containing some of the most influential, currently publishing journals in each field. As a rule of thumb, each field should be represented by more or less than ten positions, chosen by their [[impact factor]]s and other ratings.
''Note'': there are many [[List of science magazines|science magazine]]s that are not scientific journals, including ''[[Scientific American]]'', ''[[New Scientist]]'', ''[[Australasian Science]]'' and others. They are not listed here.
For periodicals in the social sciences and humanities, see [[list of social science journals]].

In [[astronomy]], the '''local standard of rest''' or '''LSR''' follows the mean motion of material in the [[Milky Way]] in the neighborhood of the [[Sun]].<ref name= Shu>{{cite book |title=The Physical Universe |author= Frank H Shu |page= 261 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v_6PbAfapSAC&pg=PA261 |isbn=0-935702-05-9 |date=1982 |publisher=University Science Books}}</ref> The path of this material is not precisely circular.<ref name=Binney>{{cite book |title=Galactic Astronomy |author1=James Binney |author2=Michael Merrifield |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arYYRoYjKacC&pg=PA536 |page= 536 |date=1998 |isbn=0-691-02565-7 |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]}}</ref> The Sun follows the '''solar circle''' ([[Ellipse#Eccentricity|eccentricity]] ''e'' < 0.1 ) at a speed of about 255 km/s in a clockwise direction when viewed from the [[galactic coordinates|galactic north pole]] at a radius of ‚âà 8.34 [[kiloparsec|kpc]]<ref name=R14>{{cite journal | author = Reid, M. |display-authors=etal | title = Trigonometric Parallaxes of High Mass Star Forming Regions: The Structure and Kinematics of the Milky Way | date = 10 March 2014 | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/783/2/130 | pages = 130 (14pp) | issue = 2 | volume = 783 | bibcode=2014ApJ...783..130R | arxiv=1401.5377}}</ref> about the center of the galaxy near [[Sgr A*]], and has only a slight motion, towards the [[solar apex]], relative to the LSR.<ref name=Reid>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bP9hZqoIfhMC&pg=PA19 |title=Mapping the Galaxy and Nearby Galaxies |editor1=F. Combes |editor2=Keiichi Wada |date=2008 |publisher=Springer |isbn=0-387-72767-1 |author= Mark Reid |display-authors= etal |chapter=Mapping the Milky Way and the Local Group |pages=19‚Äì20}}</ref><ref name=motion>The Sun's [[peculiar motion]] relative to the LSR is 13.4 km/s. See, for example, {{cite book |author1=Binney, J. |author2=Merrifield, M. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=op. cit. |isbn=0-691-02565-7 |chapter=¬ß10.6}} or {{cite journal |title=On the distance to the Ophiuchus star-forming region |journal=Astron. Nachr. |volume=AN 329 |doi= 10.1002/asna.200710827 |arxiv=0709.0505 |date=2008 |page=12; ¬ß2.3 |author=E.E. Mamajek|bibcode = 2008AN....329...10M }}</ref>
The LSR velocity is anywhere from 202‚Äì241 km/s.<ref name=Majewski>{{cite journal |title=Precision Astrometry, Galactic Mergers, Halo Substructure and Local Dark Matter |author=Steven R. Majewski1 |journal=Proceedings of IAU Symposium 248 |arxiv=0801.4927 |date=2008|bibcode = 2008IAUS..248..450M |doi = 10.1017/S1743921308019790 |volume=3 }}</ref> In 2014, [[very-long-baseline interferometry]] observations of [[Astrophysical maser#Star-forming regions|maser emission]] in high mass star forming regions placed tight constraints on combinations of kinematic parameters such as the circular orbit speed of the Sun (Œò<sub>0</sub> + V<sub>‚òâ</sub> = 255.2 ¬± 5.1 km/s).<ref name=R14 /> There is significant correlation between the circular motion of the solar circle, the [[Stellar kinematics#Space velocity|solar peculiar motion]], and the predicted counterrotation of star-forming regions.<ref name=R09>{{cite journal | author = Reid, M. |display-authors=etal | title = Trigonometric Parallaxes of High Mass Star Forming Regions. VI. Galactic Structure, Fundamental Parameters, and Noncircular Motions | date = 20 July 2009 | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/700/1/137 | pages = 137‚Äì148 | issue = 1 | volume = 700 | bibcode=2009ApJ...700..137R | arxiv=0902.3913}}</ref> Additionally, ''local'' estimates of the velocity of the LSR based on stars in the vicinity of the Sun<ref name=DB98>{{cite journal | author = Dehnen, W. |author2=Binney, J.J. | title = Local stellar kinematics from HIPPARCOS data | date = October 1998 | journal = [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-8711.1998.01600.x | pages = 387‚Äì394| issue = 2 | volume = 298 | bibcode=1998MNRAS.298..387D | arxiv=astro-ph/9710077}}</ref> may potentially yield different results than ''global'' estimates derived from motions relative to the Galactic center.<ref name=Bovy>{{cite journal | author = Bovy, J. |display-authors=etal | title = The Milky Way's Circular-velocity Curve between 4 and 14 kpc from APOGEE data | date = 10 November 2012 | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/759/2/131 | pages = 131 (20pp) | issue = 2 | volume = 759 | bibcode=2012ApJ...759..131B | arxiv=1209.0759}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Comoving_and_proper_distances#Comoving_coordinates|Comoving coordinates]] for an example of another convenient astronomical reference frame.
