'''Wilhelm Heinrich Prestele''' (or '''William Henry Prestele''') (13 October 1838 ‚Äì 16 August 1895) was a botanical artist known for his lithographs and watercolor work commissioned by the [[US Department of Agriculture]].<ref name=usda/><ref name=dfn/>
== Biography == [[Image:prestele raspberry.jpg|right|thumb|Lithograph created by Prestele of ''[[Rubus crataegifolius]]'' (Korean Raspberry) and ''[[Rubus ursinus]]'' (California Blackberry).]]
Prestele was born on October 13, 1838, in [[Grand Duchy of Hesse|Hesse-Darmstadt]], [[Germany]], to Franz Joseph Martin Prestele and Karoline Russ. The family emigrated to America in 1843, settling first in New York and later in the [[Amana Colonies]] in [[Iowa]].<ref name=dfn/> His father, known in America as Joseph Prestele, was also a painter and lithographer of flowers and fruits and prior to emigrating had been head gardener for King [[Ludwig I of Bavaria]] as well as a staff artist for a time at the Royal Botanical Garden in Munich.<ref name=djk/><ref name=jwen/> From his father he learned the arts of watercolor and lithography.<ref name=dfn/>
In the late 1850s, Prestele moved to New York, and in 1861 he joined the Union Army as a private in a regiment of New York volunteers. He was wounded at the battle of [[Antietam]] in 1862 and spent the remainder of his service period recovering in hospital.<ref name=dfn/> Sometime around 1863, he married an Irish woman named Anne, and with her he had three children‚ÄîMargaret (1864), Frances (ca. 1869), and Emma (1870)‚Äîbefore Anne died in 1871 or 1872.<ref name=dfn/>
In 1867, at the age of 29, William was hired to make a series of nurserymen‚Äôs [[lithography|plates]] by Illinois nursery owner Franklin Kelsey Phoenix. He moved his family from New York to Bloomington, Illinois, for this project. No plates from this project are known to have survived, but a write-up in the August 1869 edition of ''Gardener's Monthly and Horticultural Advertiser'' praised them in robust terms: "We have now before us a fruit piece... prepared by W. H. Prestele. We are in the habit of admiring European art in this line, and have often wished Americans could successfully compete with it. We now have it here. We never saw anything of the kind better executed from any part of the world".<ref name=dfn/>
When this relationship ended in 1871, William briefly went into business with L. B. Littlefield, publishing fruit and flower plates. In 1875, he moved his family to Iowa, not far from the Amana community where he was raised, and married his second wife, Susanna Gefaller.<ref name=dfn/> With Susanna, who died in 1882, he had a daughter, Lillian.<ref name=dfn/> He set up as a lithographer in [[Iowa City]] and practiced this trade for a decade or so.
[[File:Pomological Watercolor POM00004651.jpg|thumb|Watercolor of wild cherry (''Prunus avium'') by William Henry Prestele, 1892.]]
On August 1, 1887, he was appointed as the first artist on the staff of the recently formed Pomological Division of the United States Department of Agriculture in Washington, D.C. He was assigned to make life-size watercolors of native grapes intended as illustrations for a monograph by [[Thomas Volney Munson]] of Denison, Texas, a leading authority on native grapes.<ref name=djk/><ref name=jwen/><ref name=issue/> He worked from live and dried specimens sent to him by Munson, making color sketches of details that Munson would then review; Prestele would then use these detail drawings would to create a life-size painting of the species.<ref name=usda/> The U.S. Secretary of Agriculture eventually decided the cost of printing the monograph with the illustrations would be prohibitive, so it was never published in its intended form, though Munson went on to use the text he wrote as the foundation for his highly regarded book ''Foundations of American Grape Culture''.<ref name=usda/> Munson's book was illustrated with photographs instead of with Prestele's watercolors, which remained in the collection of the USDA.
Prestele's paintings are noted for their naturalness and attention to botanical accuracy.<ref name=djk/> Over a hundred of his watercolors of grapes and other fruit are held in the National Agricultural Library's [[United States National Agricultural Library#Pomological Watercolor Collection|Pomological Watercolor Collection]].
He died in Arlington, Virginia on August 16, 1895, and was buried at Arlington National Cemetery. A collection of his papers spanning the years 1887-1891 is held by the USDA National Agricultural Library Special Collections and comprises original watercolors and drawings, plant specimens, and other materials, including work related to the planned Munson monograph.<ref name=usda/>
==Further reading== * Munson, Thomas Volney. ''Foundations of American Grape Culture''. New York: Orange Judd Company, c. 1909. * van Ravenswaay, Charles. ''Drawn From Nature: The Botanical Art of Joseph Prestele and His Sons''. Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington, D.C. 1984.
== References == {{reflist | refs= <ref name=usda>[http://specialcollections.nal.usda.gov/guide-collections/wilhelm-heinrich-william-henry-prestele-papers "Wilhelm Heinrich (William Henry) Prestele Papers"]. NAL Collections: National Agricultural Library.</ref>
<ref name=dfn>[http://prestele.blogspot.com/ "Drawings from Nature"].</ref>
<ref name=djk>Kevles, Daniel J. [http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/how-to-trademark-a-fruit-16888575 "How to Trademark a Fruit"]. ''Smithsonian'', August 2011.</ref>
<ref name=jwen>White, James J., and Erik A. Neumann. "The Collection of Pomological Watercolors at the U.S. National Arboretum". ''Huntia: A Journal of Botanical History'' 4:2 (January 1982), pp. 103‚Äì104.</ref>
<ref name=issue>Although USDA states that Prestele created the series of wild-grape paintings in the 1880s, White and Neumann date the paintings to the 1860s.</ref> }}
